overview.description: Liquidity Network enabling fast cross-chain token transfers between Ethereum L1 and L2s using optimistic message passing with Bonder-provided liquidity

trust_model.multisig_role: Manages bridge parameters, bond sizes, challenge periods, and Bonder whitelist

bonder_requirements.slashing_penalty: Fraudulent transfer value + 10% bounty to challenger
bonder_requirements.fallback_mechanism: If all Bonders offline, transfers settle via native rollup exit (7+ day delay)

trust_model.decentralization_status: Working toward fully decentralizing Bonder role

how_it_works: 1. User sends tokens on source chain
2. Bonder runs verifier node, validates source chain state
3. Bonder bonds 110% collateral and mints hTokens on destination
4. hTokens swapped to canonical tokens via AMM on destination
5. Transfer roots batched and sent to L1 via native AMB (~1 week)
6. 24-hour challenge period for anyone to dispute invalid roots

challenge_system.challenger_stake: Equal to challenged transfer root bond
challenge_system.open_source_watcher: Challenge Watcher available for anyone to run

security_mechanism.htoken_mechanism: Specialized bridge tokens (hETH, hDAI) that can transfer rollup-to-rollup in batches, converted via AMM to canonical tokens

core_contracts: Accounting.sol - Bonder collateral and credit tracking
Bridge.sol - Base withdrawal and settlement logic
L1_Bridge.sol - L1 transfer operations and root bonding
L2_Bridge.sol - L2 minting and cross-chain transfers

bug_bounty.note: DeFiSafety found no bug bounty program in documentation - significant gap

privacy_analysis.timing_correlation: HIGH - Transfer times visible on both chains
privacy_analysis.address_linkage: HIGH - Same address typically used on both chains
privacy_analysis.bonder_observation: MEDIUM - Whitelisted Bonders see all transfer data
privacy_analysis.recommendation: Not suitable for privacy-focused transfers. Consider shielded bridges (Aztec, Webb) for privacy needs.

operational_security.oracle_dependency: None - relies on native chain AMBs

warnings: Invalid message bundles could succeed if unchallenged for 24 hours
Destination token contracts may be upgradeable
Destination chain AMBs could censor messages

security_rating_justification: Hop Protocol uses an optimistic security model with economic guarantees (110% collateral, 24-hour challenge period) that has proven effective with no exploits since 2021 launch. However, the permissioned Bonder whitelist, lack of documented bug bounty program, and reliance on active challenge watchers introduce trust assumptions. The 2-of-3 multisig control over critical parameters and 24-hour timelock (below recommended 48-hour) present moderate centralization risks. Multiple audits before launch and clean security track record are positive indicators.

primary_risks: Permissioned Bonder whitelist - not fully decentralized
If all watchers fail, invalid transfers could succeed
mitigating_factors: No exploits or security incidents since 2021 launch
110% collateral requirement creates strong economic disincentives
Multiple pre-launch audits with all findings addressed
Fallback to native rollup exits if Bonders offline
Active DAO governance with HOP token
risk_summary.worst_case_scenario: If all Bonders go offline, transfers experience standard rollup exit delays (7+ days). If a malicious Bonder submits invalid transfer root AND no one challenges for 24 hours, fraudulent withdrawal could succeed (capped by Bonder's collateral).

gaps_and_missing_data: Specific number of active Bonders not publicly documented
Bug bounty program status needs verification
Multisig key holder identities not fully disclosed
Detailed incident response procedures not documented
